_emerg_resp.LEPCCoordinationReason: The facility coordinates with the local CUPA in CA which is LEPC equivalent

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program  Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP)  Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Cali-Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Cali-Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Cali-Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 
Process Name                        | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration        Anhydrous Ammonia            54,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obl

igations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)
3. The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

1.2.1 Facility Overview

Cali-Cold Storage operates a commercial cold storage for table grapes in Delano, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:
(8) Rooms
(5) Precools
(2) Hallways
(1) Staging/Dock

1.2.2 Facility Location

Cali-Cold Storage is located at 33398 Woollomes Ave, Delano, CA 93215. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 35.748385, -119.143788. The facility is located approximately 5 miles east of state highway 99 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.

Flood Hazards

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in an area of minimal flood hazard.

Seismic Susceptibility

Cali-Cold Storage is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that faults within close proximity are not considered high risk:
Pond Fault - <150 Years
New Hope Fault - <150 Years
Poso Creek Fault - <1,600,000 Years
Mt. Poso Fault - <1,600,000 Years 

The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Cali-Cold Storage has a 1-2% chance of experiencing potentially minor-damage due to ground shaking in 2018.

1.2.3 Description of Covered Process

Flooded System

The refrigerated areas are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.

All control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly outside the machinery room.

Process Classi

fication

The ammonia refrigeration system at Cali-Cold Storage consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Cali-Cold Storage is treated as a single process.

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Cali-Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Cali-Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. 

1.4 Five Year Accident Histor
y
Cali-Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Cali-Cold Storages emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- Cal/OSHAs Emergency Action Plan  Title 8 CCR §3220
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans  Title 29 CFR §1910.38
- Cal/OSHAs Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements]  Title 8

CCR §5189(n)
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]  Title 29 CFR §1910.119(n)
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements]  Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 §2765.1-2765.2
- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements]  Title 40 CFR §68.90-96
- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures]  Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 §2731

Strategically, Cali - Cold Storage has chosen to be a non-responding stationary source. 

Our employees will not respond to accidental releases of ammonia. In lieu of responding to accidental releases, Cali - Cold Storage is implementing the following protocols:
The facility is included in the community emergency response plan developed under Title 42 USC §11003.
Since the only regulated chemicals at the facility are flammable substances, Cali - Cold Storage coordinates emergency response actions with the local fire department. This line should only be kept if the facility is only subject to the program because of flammable substances.
Appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.
Annual emergency response coordination activities are performed (Section 1.5.1).
Annual notification exercises are performed (Section 1.5.2).

1.5.1 Emergency Response Coordination Activities

The purpose of emergency response coordination activities is to coordinate response needs with local emergency planning and response organizations. The intent is for local response organizations to be made aware of the regulated substances at Cali - Cold Storage, their quantities, the risks presented by the covered processes, and the resources and capabilities at our facility to respond to an accidental release of a regulated substance. The emergency response coordination activiti

es will consist of the following:
Coordinations will be completed at least annually. Additional coordinations will be made to account for changes at our facility that may affect the community emergency response plan.
Coordinations will include Cali - Cold Storages emergency response plan, updated emergency contact information, and any other information necessary for developing and implementing the local emergency response plan.

Coordination activities will be appropriately documented. The coordination records will include the names of individuals involved and their contact information (phone number, email address, and organizational affiliations), dates of coordination activities, and nature of coordination activities.

The disclosure of information classified or restricted by the Department of Defense or other Federal agencies or contractors of such agencies is controlled by applicable laws, regulations, or executive orders concerning the release of that classified or restricted information.

1.5.2 Emergency Response Notification Exercises

At least once per calendar year, Cali - Cold Storage will conduct an exercise of the facilitys emergency response notifications mechanism. The facility will record each notification exercise utilizing PSMWriter.

Alternatively, the facility may meet the notification requirements through other exercises conducted to meet other Federal, state or local requirements, provided that the necessary notification is performed. Additionally, if a notification is made in response to an accidental release, this would also satisfy the notification requirement.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Cali-Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Cali-Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Cali-Col

d Storages ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Cali-Cold Storages management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Cali-Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Cali-Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Cali-Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Cali-Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Cali-Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
